description: Former Council members and ex-BCI designers attend forums, offering apologies and joining discussions on new, inclusive governance based on shared memory, trust, and reconciliation. The tone across Stenograd shifts from blame toward constructive debate on the city’s future.

Oksana Lintz formally archives the 'Forgiveness Ledger,' choosing not to release the raw data. Instead, she directs support and resources to youth-led organizers, encouraging them to facilitate open forums and imagine a future-oriented approach to justice.

Inspired by Oksana's decision, youth leaders—many from families impacted by early BCI pilot harms—organize open forums. They call on adults and system architects to be accountable, shifting the citywide debate toward a new vision for governance.

Youth-led reverse trials are held across key plazas. Adults, including former Council members, are asked to answer for BCI-era decisions. Public admissions and emotional apologies foster citywide debate and reflection.

Galvanized by the forums and trials, youth propose a draft city charter focused on transparency, inclusion, and collective memory. Neighborhood assemblies debate its provisions as intergenerational cooperation grows.
